body:
**If this issue affects you, please react with a üëç (thumbs up emoji) to the initial post.**

Your feedback helps us prioritize which bugs to investigate and address first.

![Views](https://api.views-badge.org/badge/st-issue-10674)

performed_via_github_app.name: GitHub Actions
performed_via_github_app.description: Automate your workflow from idea to production

body:
Hi @alex-bork , 

Thank you for filing this issue.

Can you provide more information on what you are trying to do? Can you apply your css to the element that has the class?

The other element in your picture is a wrapper used to manage the interaction of the border + padding and the width. 

Laura

Hi @sfc-gh-lwilby ,

I try to build a kind of a tile with st.container. I thought that if I give the container the key attribute, I would be able to use some CSS on it, in order to change the background color for example. It seems that not only the container does not get the CSS class, some of the wdgets behave the same way. That is just what I didn't expect. So in order to select the container I would have to select its content using the class from the key attribute, select its parent and select its parent. From what I know about CSS is it is easier to get to the children that to n parents above. 

Best Regards

Thanks @alex-bork , 

I think I see the issue you are having when running your code and adding the background style onto the element with the CSS class. There is a difference in size between the `stVerticalBlockBorderWrapper` and the `stVerticalBlock` so for the background colour applying it to `stVerticalBlock` is not adequate. Does this fully describe the issue? What other widgets are you working with?

Laura

Hi @sfc-gh-lwilby,

maybe we should go through an example, so I get an idea how to handle that behavior. Let's say I want apply a background-color to st.countainer upto 100% of its high and width (marked with blue + green color on my first screenshot). How would I do that using CSS? Is that possible?

Best Regards
Alex

> Hi [@sfc-gh-lwilby](https://github.com/sfc-gh-lwilby),
> 
> maybe we should go through an example, so I get an idea how to handle that behavior. Let's say I want apply a background-color to st.countainer upto 100% of its high and width (marked with blue + green color on my first screenshot). How would I do that using CSS? Is that possible?
> 
> Best Regards Alex

Hi Alex, 

I think there are two conversations going on here and I want to separate them out for clarity. 

1) It sounds like here you are looking for help with applying the styles on your app. I think it would be better for this type of question to post in the community forum https://discuss.streamlit.io/ where there are many community members that can help. Based on the investigation I did, I would try to grab the `stVerticalBlockBorderWrapper`, probably by traversing to the parent like you suggested previously. 

2) Potentially a gap/bug in the advanced theming implementation. For this, can you let me know if I am describing your issue correctly above? Also, if you are having the same issue with other widgets, can you let me know which ones? I am planning on checking with the team on whether it is feasible to move these class definitions.

**To help Streamlit prioritize this feature, react with a üëç (thumbs up emoji) to the initial post.**

Your vote helps us identify which enhancements matter most to our users.

![Visits](https://hits.seeyoufarm.com/api/count/incr/badge.svg?url=https%3A%2F%2Fgithub.com%2Fstreamlit%2Fstreamlit%2Fissues%2F10674&title=visits&edge_flat=false)

performed_via_github_app.name: GitHub Actions
performed_via_github_app.description: Automate your workflow from idea to production

body:
Hi Laura,

I think it is actually more like the first point you mentioned in your last post. I wasn't aware of how I can get the parent of the parent, so I could add a new background-color to the st.container. I have finally found a solution for that issue using the following CSS-selector:

div:has(>div>div[class*="hr_app_tyle_cont_"])

I don't know if that is the best way to do it, but it works at least.  :-)

Best Regards
Alex

issue.title: [AdvancedLayouts] Stretch height and fixed height in vertical layouts.

repository.name: streamlit
repository.description: Streamlit ‚Äî A faster way to build and share data apps.

issue.body: ## Describe your changes Note: `stVerticalBlockBorderWrapper` is removed, instead use `stVerticalBlock` for custom styles on containers. May break some users using this class for custom theming styles. Styles to handle `height="stretch"` for `st.code` and `st.form` elements when they are in a fixed height container. Styles to handle `height=int` in vertical layouts with other elements. Tests for different vertical layouts and nested container scenarios. ## GitHub Issue Link (if applicable) Closes #10674 ## Testing Plan Unit Tests (JS and/or Python) ‚úÖ E2E Tests ‚úÖ --- **Contribution License Agreement** By submitting this pull request you agree that all contributions to this project are made under the Apache 2.0 license.
